headline.main: Fear and Poverty Sicken Many Migrant Workers in U.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: Francisco Plaza, a 35-year-old farm worker from Mexico, made a rare visit to a doctor last year after he suddenly lost a lot of weight. The doctor told him that he had diabetes and ordered him to take two medications that cost $134 a month. But Mr. Plaza, who prunes fruit trees for $6.25 an hour, often skips his medicine, saying he cannot afford it after paying for food and rent.

headline.main: Valletta Journal; Malta Greets the Pope Like a Beloved Spa Client

docs.abstract: John Paul II arrives in Valletta, Malta, on final stop of six-day pilgrimage in footsteps of St Paul the Apostle, which also took him to Greece and Syria; is greeted with warm and affectionate solicitude by Maltese, 98 percent of whom are Roman Catholics; photo; maps (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: John Paul II arrived in Malta today to find himself facing a vast platform crammed with jostling journalists, all craning for an intimate shot. The bent, fragile pope pointed at the photographers, then folded his fingers in a hand gesture more common to Roman taxi drivers than popes. It means, roughly, ''What the heck do you want from me?'' The pope, who turns 81 later this month, seemed to be responding -- rather roguishly -- to alarmed news coverage of his physical condition, which seemed tested by a six-day pilgrimage in the footsteps of St. Paul the Apostle that took him to Greece and Syria before Malta.
